elements.content: Six new calcium metal−organic frameworks [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] (1), [Ca(ABDC)(DMF)] (2), [Ca3(BTC)2(DMF)2(H2O)2]·3H2O (3), [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)] (4), [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)2] (5), and one modification of [Ca(H2dhtp)2(H2O)2] (6), (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide; BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate anion; ABDC = 2-aminobenzene-1,4-dicarboxylate anion; BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate anion; H2dhtp = 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalate anion) were synthesized from calcium ions and aromatic carboxylic acids by solvothermal reactions and microwave-assisted solvothermal reactions. The single crystal structure analysis showed that all complexes display three-dimensional structures containing various inorganic motifs with helical or straight one-dimensional inorganic chains (1−3), pentagonal bipyramidal dimers (4 and 6), or discrete octahedra (5) connected through organic linkers and forming DMF- or water-coordinated neutral frameworks. It is also interesting that compounds 1−5 undergo dissolution/reorganization reactions comprising a break and reformation of the Ca−O bond and leading to destruction/construction structural transformations. Compounds 1−5 were further characterized by thermal gravimetric analysis, powder X-ray diffraction, UV−vis, infrared, and PL spectroscopy.

The single crystal structure analysis showed that all complexes display three-dimensional structures containing various inorganic motifs with helical or straight one-dimensional inorganic chains (1-3), pentagonal bipyramidal dimers (4 and 6), or discrete octahedra (5) connected through organic linkers and forming DMF- or water-coordinated neutral frameworks. It is also interesting that compounds 1-5 undergo dissolution/reorganization reactions comprising a break and reformation of the Ca-O bond and leading to destruction/construction structural transformations. Compounds 1-5 were further characterized by thermal gravimetric analysis, powder X-ray diffraction, UV-vis, infrared, and PL spectroscopy.

elements.content: A series of six new calcium metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been prepared by solvothermal, microwave-assisted solvothermal, and dissolution/reorganization reactions. Secondary-building units of helical or straight one-dimensional inorganic chains, dimers, and discrete octahedral inorganic motifs were found in these calcium MOFs.
elements.clean_text: A series of six new calcium metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been prepared by solvothermal, microwave-assisted solvothermal, and dissolution/reorganization reactions. Secondary-building units of helical or straight one-dimensional inorganic chains, dimers, and discrete octahedral inorganic motifs were found in these calcium MOFs.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted the interest of the chemistry community due to their wide constructing topologies and potential applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, magnetism, luminescence, and drug delivery. In the synthesis of MOFs, metal ions are generally considered as connectors and organic polyanions (such as carboxylates, sulfonates, phosphonates, etc.) as linkers. The MOF structure is then obtained by a combination of these connectors and linkers. Among the linkers, aromatic carboxylate anions are of special interest as they have a rigid organic skeleton and strong coordination ability toward many metals. Thanks to this coordination, these linkers aggregate metal ions into clusters that are referred to as secondary building units (SBU). As summarized in the literature, the SBUs also act as essential motifs for the construction of robust frameworks. Numerous MOFs have been synthesized using various SBUs with discrete units and clusters (0D), one-dimensional (1D) chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers, and even totally inorganic three-dimensional (3D) subnetworks. The extensive coordination numbers of the metal ions also allow for various connections of metals to organic ligands that can produce supramolecular isomers and functional material with varied topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted the interest of the chemistry community due to their wide constructing topologies and potential applications in gas storage, separation, catalysis, magnetism, luminescence, and drug delivery. In the synthesis of MOFs, metal ions are generally considered as connectors and organic polyanions (such as carboxylates, sulfonates, phosphonates, etc.) as linkers. The MOF structure is then obtained by a combination of these connectors and linkers. Among the linkers, aromatic carboxylate anions are of special interest as they have a rigid organic skeleton and strong coordination ability toward many metals. Thanks to this coordination, these linkers aggregate metal ions into clusters that are referred to as secondary building units (SBU). As summarized in the literature, the SBUs also act as essential motifs for the construction of robust frameworks. Numerous MOFs have been synthesized using various SBUs with discrete units and clusters (0D), one-dimensional (1D) chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers, and even totally inorganic three-dimensional (3D) subnetworks. The extensive coordination numbers of the metal ions also allow for various connections of metals to organic ligands that can produce supramolecular isomers and functional material with varied topologies.

elements.content: Moreover, the structural changes accomplished by single-crystal to single-crystal transformations and dissolution/reorganization toward the destruction/construction structural transformations are of particular interest in areas of controlling self-assembly supramolecular chemistry of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or MOFs. Such obvious structural transformations are frequently initiated by either removal/reabsorption of guests or by component changes. From the point view of supramolecular chemistry, these processes are controlled by the metal coordination number, cleavage, and reformation of bonds between a metal and ligands, hydrogen-bonding, or π−π stacking.

Such obvious structural transformations are frequently initiated by either removal/reabsorption of guests or by component changes. From the point view of supramolecular chemistry, these processes are controlled by the metal coordination number, cleavage, and reformation of bonds between a metal and ligands, hydrogen-bonding, or π-π stacking.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, there are a few papers on calcium -containing 3D metal−organic frameworks. In this paper, we report six new calcium MOFs which are synthesized from aromatic carboxylic acids and calcium ions under solvothermal conditions, in microwave-assisted reactions, and in solution processes connected with dissolution/reorganization. The structural transformations, supramolecular isomerism, and gas sorption properties are also presented.
elements.clean_text: To the best of our knowledge, there are a few papers on calcium -containing 3D metal-organic frameworks. In this paper, we report six new calcium MOFs which are synthesized from aromatic carboxylic acids and calcium ions under solvothermal conditions, in microwave-assisted reactions, and in solution processes connected with dissolution/reorganization. The structural transformations, supramolecular isomerism, and gas sorption properties are also presented.

elements.content: Chemicals of reagent grade or better were used as received. The solvothermal reactions were carried out by heating the reaction mixtures in 23-mL Teflon-lined digestion bombs to the desired temperature under autogenous pressure followed by slow cooling at 6 °C h−1 to room temperature. Microwave-assisted reactions were done in a 100 mL Teflon autoclave placed in a microwave oven (START D, Milestone, maximum power of 1200 W, 2.45 GHz) in which the precursor mixtures were heated for several minutes. Compounds 1−5 are soluble in water but insoluble in common organic solvents. The phase purity was examined by powder X-ray diffraction before further characterizations (). Elemental analyses were carried out to confirm the composition of the organic part of the prepared samples. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA), using a DuPont TA Q50 analyzer, were performed on powder samples under flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The gas sorption isotherms were measured at 77 K for N2 and H2, and 298 K for CO2 were measured volumetrically in the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 adsorption apparatus. The temperatures were achieved by using a Dewar with a circulating jacket connected to a thermostatic bath. About 120 mg of adsorbent samples was used for the gas adsorption studies. The initial outgassing process was carried out under a vacuum at 423 K for 12 h. The free space of the system was determined by using the helium gas. The degas procedure was repeated on the same sample between measurements for 5 h. Ultrahigh purity grade CO2, H2, N2, and He were used as received.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

Chemicals of reagent grade or better were used as received. The solvothermal reactions were carried out by heating the reaction mixtures in 23-mL Teflon-lined digestion bombs to the desired temperature under autogenous pressure followed by slow cooling at 6 °C h-1 to room temperature. Microwave-assisted reactions were done in a 100 mL Teflon autoclave placed in a microwave oven (START D, Milestone, maximum power of 1200 W, 2.45 GHz) in which the precursor mixtures were heated for several minutes. Compounds 1-5 are soluble in water but insoluble in common organic solvents. The phase purity was examined by powder X-ray diffraction before further characterizations (). Elemental analyses were carried out to confirm the composition of the organic part of the prepared samples. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA), using a DuPont TA Q50 analyzer, were performed on powder samples under flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The gas sorption isotherms were measured at 77 K for N2 and H2, and 298 K for CO2 were measured volumetrically in the Micromeritics ASAP 2020 adsorption apparatus. The temperatures were achieved by using a Dewar with a circulating jacket connected to a thermostatic bath. About 120 mg of adsorbent samples was used for the gas adsorption studies. The initial outgassing process was carried out under a vacuum at 423 K for 12 h. The free space of the system was determined by using the helium gas. The degas procedure was repeated on the same sample between measurements for 5 h. Ultrahigh purity grade CO2, H2, N2, and He were used as received.

elements.content: A reaction mixture of bis(2-hydroxyethyl)1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (C12H14O6, H2BHET, 0.0508 g, 0.2 mmol), Ca(NO3)2 ·4H2O (0.0945 g, 0.4 mmol), H2O (1.0 mL), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 5.0 mL) was stirred for 20 min at room temperature forming a homogeneous solution with a pH value of 6.40. The solution was heated at 150 °C for 2 days. Colorless crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with DMF, dried at 50 °C in an oven, and collected with the yield of 0.027 g (47.99%, based on the H2BHET reagent). Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 43.90/44.74; N, 4.65/4.74; H, 4.41/4.44% for 1. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3505(br), 3467(br), 3304(br), 1667(w), 1618(w), 1558(s), 1509(m), 1438(s), 1394(s), 1312(w), 1108(w), 1021(w), 869(w), 846(w), 700(w), 674(w), 513(w).

elements.content: The replacement of DMF with water carried by dissolution/reorganization of compounds 1, 4, and 5 resulted in new complexes 1a and 4a, which are known structures with formulas [Ca(BDC)(H2O)3] and [Ca(H2dhtp)2(H2O)2], respectively. The preparation was done by immersing the starting compounds in 50 mL of aqueous methanol (95 vol %) and stirring for 4 days at room temperature. After most of the solvent was removed and the rest slowly evaporated to dryness, crystalline samples of 1a and 4a were obtained. Compound 5 converted to 4a similarly to compound 4.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ca(BDC)(H2O)3] (1a ) and [Ca(H2dhtp)2(H2O)2] (4a or CPO-20)

The replacement of DMF with water carried by dissolution/reorganization of compounds 1, 4, and 5 resulted in new complexes 1a and 4a, which are known structures with formulas [Ca(BDC)(H2O)3] and [Ca(H2dhtp)2(H2O)2], respectively. The preparation was done by immersing the starting compounds in 50 mL of aqueous methanol (95 vol %) and stirring for 4 days at room temperature. After most of the solvent was removed and the rest slowly evaporated to dryness, crystalline samples of 1a and 4a were obtained. Compound 5 converted to 4a similarly to compound 4.

elements.content:
Heating of compound 4a at 200 °C for 5 h results in its dehydration to a new phase denoted 4b.

Single-Crystal Structure Analysis

The diffraction measurements were performed on Bruker AXS KAPPA APEX II diffractometer (Mo−Kα radiation, graphite monochromator, λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data were collected with a combination of ω and ϕ scans. All data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, and the program SADABS in APEX2 was used for the absorption correction. On the basis of systematic absences and statistics of intensity distribution, the space groups were determined to be Pnma for 1 and 2, C2 for 3, P1̅ for 4, C2/c for 5, and P1̅ for 6. The structures were solved with Ca atom being disclosed first, followed by the atoms of O, N, and C located on successive difference Fourier maps. The H atoms were added in idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. In compound 3, the best diffraction data set after several attempts is still of limited quality. The heavily disordered coordinated-DMF molecules and oxygen atoms are treated as isotropic to subtract the solvent contribution and be satisfactorily modeled. All calculations were performed by using SHELXTL programs in APEX2. Crystallographic data are given in Table . Selected Ca−O bond lengths and corresponding H-bond data are listed in (Tables S1 and S2).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of [Ca(H2dhtp)2] (4b or CPO-21)

Heating of compound 4a at 200 °C for 5 h results in its dehydration to a new phase denoted 4b.

Single-Crystal Structure Analysis

The diffraction measurements were performed on Bruker AXS KAPPA APEX II diffractometer (Mo-Kα radiation, graphite monochromator, λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data were collected with a combination of ω and ϕ scans. All data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects, and the program SADABS in APEX2  was used for the absorption correction. On the basis of systematic absences and statistics of intensity distribution, the space groups were determined to be Pnma for 1 and 2, C2 for 3, P1̅ for 4, C2/c for 5, and P1̅ for 6. The structures were solved with Ca atom being disclosed first, followed by the atoms of O, N, and C located on successive difference Fourier maps. The H atoms were added in idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. In compound 3, the best diffraction data set after several attempts is still of limited quality. The heavily disordered coordinated-DMF molecules and oxygen atoms are treated as isotropic to subtract the solvent contribution and be satisfactorily modeled. All calculations were performed by using SHELXTL programs in APEX2. Crystallographic data are given in Table . Selected Ca-O bond lengths and corresponding H-bond data are listed in  (Tables S1 and S2).

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 1 possesses an extended 3D framework. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ca atom, one BDC ligand, one DMF, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The Ca(II) ion is eight-coordinated and binds six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups belonging to four BDC ligands, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom from DMF with the typical Ca−O bond values from 2.366(5) to 2.557(3) Å. The BDC anion bonds to four different Ca(II) ions and adopts a symmetric tetradentate (κ2)-(κ1-κ2-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). Each carboxylate group chelates one calcium atom. As shown in Figure b, CaO8 distorted tetragonal antiprisms share edges and create inorganic motifs in the form of zigzag 1D chains running along the a axis. These chains are linked together by μ4 links of the BDC ligands in two directions to generate the 3D MOF of 1 (Figure c) with rhomboidal channels running along the a-axis, which have a cross section of about 15.5 × 5.6 Å2. The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. The solvent accessible volume (SAV) calculated without including DMF and water molecules by PLATON analysis is 646.2 Å3, which is 47.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 1 can be described as a sra net (), as defined by the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource, or a uninodal 4-connected net with Schläfli symbol of {42.63.8}, determined using TOPOS. This topology, despite its simplicity, is rather unusual and, in the group of metal carboxylates, it was found in cobalt(II) coordination complex with 1,3-benzenecarboxylate and in cadmium(II) compound with cysteic acid.

Results and Discussion

Structural Description of [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] (1)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 1 possesses an extended 3D framework. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ca atom, one BDC ligand, one DMF, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The Ca(II) ion is eight-coordinated and binds six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups belonging to four BDC ligands, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom from DMF with the typical Ca-O bond values from 2.366(5) to 2.557(3) Å. The BDC anion bonds to four different Ca(II) ions and adopts a symmetric tetradentate (κ2)-(κ1-κ2-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). Each carboxylate group chelates one calcium atom. As shown in Figure b, CaO8 distorted tetragonal antiprisms share edges and create inorganic motifs in the form of zigzag 1D chains running along the a axis. These chains are linked together by μ4 links of the BDC ligands in two directions to generate the 3D MOF of 1 (Figure c) with rhomboidal channels running along the a-axis, which have a cross section of about 15.5 × 5.6 Å2. The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. The solvent accessible volume (SAV) calculated without including DMF and water molecules by PLATON analysis is 646.2 Å3, which is 47.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 1 can be described as a sra net (), as defined by the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource, or a uninodal 4-connected net with Schläfli symbol of {42.63.8}, determined using TOPOS. This topology, despite its simplicity, is rather unusual and, in the group of metal carboxylates, it was found in cobalt(II) coordination complex with 1,3-benzenecarboxylate and in cadmium(II) compound with cysteic acid.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 2 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca atom, one ABDC ligand, and two DMF molecules (Figure a). The Ca(II) ion is eight-coordinated and binds six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups belonging to four ABDC ligands, and two oxygen atoms from the coordinated DMF molecules with typical Ca−O bond values from 2.326(2) to 2.541(2) Å. The position of the amino groups in the benzene ring of ABDC is disordered. Each ABDC anion bonds to four Ca(II) ions with the two carboxylate groups adopting an opposite (κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ2)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). Each carboxylate group chelates to one calcium atom through its oxygen atoms as shown on the right side of Figure a. As shown in Figure b, CaO8 monocapped pentagonal bipyramids share faces to create an inorganic motif in the form of a zigzag 1D chain running along the a axis. These 1D chains are connected by the μ4-links of the ABDC ligands in two directions to generate the 3D framework of 2 (Figure c) with rhomboidal channels running along the a axis having a cross section of about 14.0 × 5.8 Å2. The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 412.7 Å3 which is 32.9% of the unit cell volume. The smaller channels and SAV compared to compound 1 are most probably given by the amino groups of the ABDC ligands which extend into the channels. The topology of compound 2 can be described as a 4,6-connected seh net () with a Schläfli symbol of {32.62.72}{34.42.64.75}.

Structural Description of [Ca(ABDC)(DMF)] (2)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 2 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca atom, one ABDC ligand, and two DMF molecules (Figure a). The Ca(II) ion is eight-coordinated and binds six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups belonging to four ABDC ligands, and two oxygen atoms from the coordinated DMF molecules with typical Ca-O bond values from 2.326(2) to 2.541(2) Å. The position of the amino groups in the benzene ring of ABDC is disordered. Each ABDC anion bonds to four Ca(II) ions with the two carboxylate groups adopting an opposite (κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ2)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). Each carboxylate group chelates to one calcium atom through its oxygen atoms as shown on the right side of Figure a. As shown in Figure b, CaO8 monocapped pentagonal bipyramids share faces to create an inorganic motif in the form of a zigzag 1D chain running along the a axis. These 1D chains are connected by the μ4-links of the ABDC ligands in two directions to generate the 3D framework of 2 (Figure c) with rhomboidal channels running along the a axis having a cross section of about 14.0 × 5.8 Å2. The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 412.7 Å3 which is 32.9% of the unit cell volume. The smaller channels and SAV compared to compound 1 are most probably given by the amino groups of the ABDC ligands which extend into the channels. The topology of compound 2 can be described as a 4,6-connected seh net () with a Schläfli symbol of {32.62.72}{34.42.64.75}.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that compound 3 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system, with a noncentric space group of C2 (No. 5). The asymmetric unit contains three crystallographically independent Ca centers, two BTC ligands, two DMF, two coordinated water molecules, and three lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit (Figure a). The Ca(1) site is eight-coordinated by six oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of four BTC ligands, one oxygen atom of the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom of DMF. The Ca(2) center is seven-coordinated by six oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of five BTC ligands and one oxygen atom of DMF. The Ca(3) site is also seven-coordinated by five oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of four BTC ligands, one oxygen atom of the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom of DMF. The BTC ligands display two different kinds of coordination environments. One type of the BTC ligands binds to seven calcium atoms with three carboxylate groups adopting a heptadentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ2-κ1)-μ7 coordination mode (Figure a). The other type of the BTC ligands connects to six calcium atoms with three carboxylate groups adopting a hexadentate (κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a). All of the Ca−O bonds distances range from 2.258(7) to 2.562(4) Å () which is comparable to distances reported for other calcium MOFs. As shown in Figure b, the Ca(1)O8, Ca(2)O7, and Ca(3)O7 polyhedra share edges in such a way that they form a left-handed helical chain running along the c axis. Compound 3 is worth noting for its chiral structure built from an achiral ligand as a linker. This is a very unique feature in the Ca MOFs group, as only a few chiral compounds have been prepared from achiral precursors up to now. The helical chains are connected by the BTC ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure c) containing channels between the chains. The coordinated DMF molecules are disordered and point toward the channels. The channels run along the c axis and have a cross section of 6.6 × 5.3 Å2 (O(13)···O(13) × O(1)···O(6), considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). SAV calculated without including DMF and water molecules by PLATON analysis is 1664.7 Å3, which is 48.7% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 3 has a new network () corresponding to a 5,5,6,6,7-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {3.46.5.63.74}{32.46.52}{33.44.5.62}{33.45.54.64.75}{33.48.53.6}.

Structural Description of [Ca3(BTC)2(DMF)2(H2O)2]⋅3H2O (3)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that compound 3 crystallizes in a monoclinic crystal system, with a noncentric space group of C2 (No. 5). The asymmetric unit contains three crystallographically independent Ca centers, two BTC ligands, two DMF, two coordinated water molecules, and three lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit (Figure a). The Ca(1) site is eight-coordinated by six oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of four BTC ligands, one oxygen atom of the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom of DMF. The Ca(2) center is seven-coordinated by six oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of five BTC ligands and one oxygen atom of DMF. The Ca(3) site is also seven-coordinated by five oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups of four BTC ligands, one oxygen atom of the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom of DMF. The BTC ligands display two different kinds of coordination environments. One type of the BTC ligands binds to seven calcium atoms with three carboxylate groups adopting a heptadentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ2-κ1)-μ7 coordination mode (Figure a). The other type of the BTC ligands connects to six calcium atoms with three carboxylate groups adopting a hexadentate (κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a). All of the Ca-O bonds distances range from 2.258(7) to 2.562(4) Å () which is comparable to distances reported for other calcium MOFs. As shown in Figure b, the Ca(1)O8, Ca(2)O7, and Ca(3)O7 polyhedra share edges in such a way that they form a left-handed helical chain running along the c axis. Compound 3 is worth noting for its chiral structure built from an achiral ligand as a linker. This is a very unique feature in the Ca MOFs group, as only a few chiral compounds have been prepared from achiral precursors up to now. The helical chains are connected by the BTC ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure c) containing channels between the chains. The coordinated DMF molecules are disordered and point toward the channels. The channels run along the c axis and have a cross section of 6.6 × 5.3 Å2 (O(13)⋅⋅⋅O(13) × O(1)⋅⋅⋅O(6), considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). SAV calculated without including DMF and water molecules by PLATON analysis is 1664.7 Å3, which is 48.7% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 3 has a new network () corresponding to a 5,5,6,6,7-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {3.46.5.63.74}{32.46.52}{33.44.5.62}{33.45.54.64.75}{33.48.53.6}.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 4 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, two types of half-H2dhtp ligand, and one DMF molecule (Figure a). The H2dhtp ligand displays two different types of coordination models, one binds to four calcium atoms with two carboxylate groups adopting a tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a); the other binds to six calcium atoms with two carboxylate group and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms adopting a hexadentate (κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a). The Ca(1) center is seven-coordinated and binds five oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from five H2dhtp ligands, one oxygen atom of the hydroxyl groups of H2dhtp, and one oxygen atom of DMF. Two Ca(1) polyhedra share edges and thus form of Ca2O12 dimers. These dimers are connected to each other through two carboxylic groups in a Ca(1)−O−C−O−Ca(1) bonding system of two tetradentate ligands. In addition, two hexadentate ligands bridge two dimers through their carboxyl and OH group oxygen atoms. In this way, a chain of SBUs is formed which runs along the a axis (Figure b). The chains are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to generate a 3D framework (Figure c) with channels running along the a axis direction and having a cross section of about 6.0 × 5.7 Å2 (considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 535.8 Å3, which is 41.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis () revealed that compound 4 exhibits a 4,5,6-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {42.84}{46.66.83}{48.62}2.

Structural Description of [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)] (4)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 4 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, two types of half-H2dhtp ligand, and one DMF molecule (Figure a). The H2dhtp ligand displays two different types of coordination models, one binds to four calcium atoms with two carboxylate groups adopting a tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a); the other binds to six calcium atoms with two carboxylate group and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms adopting a hexadentate (κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a). The Ca(1) center is seven-coordinated and binds five oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from five H2dhtp ligands, one oxygen atom of the hydroxyl groups of H2dhtp, and one oxygen atom of DMF. Two Ca(1) polyhedra share edges and thus form of Ca2O12 dimers. These dimers are connected to each other through two carboxylic groups in a Ca(1)-O-C-O-Ca(1) bonding system of two tetradentate ligands. In addition, two hexadentate ligands bridge two dimers through their carboxyl and OH group oxygen atoms. In this way, a chain of SBUs is formed which runs along the a axis (Figure b). The chains are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to generate a 3D framework (Figure c) with channels running along the a axis direction and having a cross section of about 6.0 × 5.7 Å2 (considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 535.8 Å3, which is 41.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis () revealed that compound 4 exhibits a 4,5,6-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {42.84}{46.66.83}{48.62}2.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 5 possesses an extended 3D structure with the space group C2/c, in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, one H2dhtp ligand, and two DMF ligands (Figure a). The calcium ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from four H2dhtp ligands and two oxygen atoms from the DMF ligands forming a CaO6 octahedron. The H2dhtp ligand binds to four calcium atoms in a tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. The SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 1009.2 Å3, which is 56.9% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 5 exhibits a 4-connected pts net () with a Schläfli symbol of {42.84}.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that compound 6 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, four H2dhtp ligands, and two H2O ligands (Figure a). The Ca center is seven-coordinated and connects to four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from four H2dhtp ligands, one oxygen atom of the hydroxyl groups from one H2dhtp ligand, and two oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules. The H2dhtp ligand displays two coordination behaviors: one of the H2dhtp ligands binds to six calcium atoms with a symmetric hexadendate (κ1-μ2)-(κ2)-(κ1-μ2)-(κ2)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a); the other type of H2dhtp ligand binds to two calcium atoms with two carboxylate groups adopting a bis-monodentate (κ1)-(κ1)-μ2 coordination mode (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, the dimers of Ca2O12 are formed by edge sharing two CaO7 polyhedra and are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to generate a 3D framework. In the structure, small channels which run along the a axis and contain coordinated water molecules are present. The SAV calculated without including water molecules by PLATON analysis is only 24.5 Å3, which is 5.0% of the unit cell volume. According to topological analysis compound 6 contains a 4,6-connected fsh net () with a Schläfli symbol of {43.63}2{46.66.83}.

elements.content: The pH values of the starting reaction mixtures range from about 3.1 to 4.4 for compounds 2−6. The higher pH value of 6.4 in the starting reaction mixture for compound 1 is given by an absence of free acid. The crystal structure analysis of 1 revealed that starting H2BHET undergoes hydrolysis under the solvothermal conditions, giving rise to the formation of H2BDC which then reacts with the Ca(II) ions in the solution. Slow hydrolysis of H2BHET at this rather high pH causes a slow release of H2BDC which consequently leads to a production of well-developed crystals of 1. Using of H2BDC under otherwise similar conditions produced only an unidentifiable amorphous material. Similar in situ transformation of organic ligands has been also reported as a protection and deprotection approach during the preparation of other MOFs.

Synthesis

The pH values of the starting reaction mixtures range from about 3.1 to 4.4 for compounds 2-6. The higher pH value of 6.4 in the starting reaction mixture for compound 1 is given by an absence of free acid. The crystal structure analysis of 1 revealed that starting H2BHET undergoes hydrolysis under the solvothermal conditions, giving rise to the formation of H2BDC which then reacts with the Ca(II) ions in the solution. Slow hydrolysis of H2BHET at this rather high pH causes a slow release of H2BDC which consequently leads to a production of well-developed crystals of 1. Using of H2BDC under otherwise similar conditions produced only an unidentifiable amorphous material. Similar in situ transformation of organic ligands has been also reported as a protection and deprotection approach during the preparation of other MOFs.

elements.content: In all cases, the reaction mixture contained DMF and water as solvents. In the case of compounds 4, 5, and 6, the mixture contained also ethanol. The compositions of the reaction mixtures and temperatures used represent optimal conditions under which products most suitable for the determination of structures using single-crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained. Except 6, all compounds contain DMF, which is embedded in the cavities of these MOFs and is coordinated to the metal atom through its oxygen. In compounds 1, 4, and 5 these DMF molecules can be replaced by water, producing compounds 1a and 4a. This paper is the first systematic approach to the study of preparation of calcium MOFs in which DMF was used as a solvent−mixture component.

elements.content: The complexes 1−6 are all 3D MOFs containing inorganic motifs ranging from isolated polyhedra to 1D chains. The rare discrete CaO6 polyhedron in compound 5 is found for the first time in the 3D calcium MOFs. The Ca2O12 and Ca2O14 dimers, which are found in compounds 4 and 6, are also rare in structures of Ca MOFs as documented by the literature listed in Table . Compound 3 is the first example of a chiral compound containing 1D helical inorganic chains as a main construction motif of a 3D calcium MOF. The use of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid as a precursor for the preparation of chiral structures with the formula of M3(BTC)2 (M = Co, Ni), Zn3(BTC)2(DMF)3(H2O)·(DMF)(H2O), and Cd4(BTC)3(DMF)2(H2O)2·6(H2O) were reported, but, up to now, no such chiral compound with alkaline-earth metals has been described. 5-Aminoisophthalic acid (H2AIP) and calcium ions can form a double helix as in a compound with the formula of {[Ca(AIP)(OH2)4](H2O)}∞. In the most reported 3D calcium MOFs containing 1D chain motifs (see Table ), these chains do not have a helical shape; it is also the case of our compounds 1 and 2.

Structural Discussion and Transformations

The complexes 1-6 are all 3D MOFs containing inorganic motifs ranging from isolated polyhedra to 1D chains. The rare discrete CaO6 polyhedron in compound 5 is found for the first time in the 3D calcium MOFs. The Ca2O12 and Ca2O14 dimers, which are found in compounds 4 and 6, are also rare in structures of Ca MOFs as documented by the literature listed in Table . Compound 3 is the first example of a chiral compound containing 1D helical inorganic chains as a main construction motif of a 3D calcium MOF. The use of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid as a precursor for the preparation of chiral structures with the formula of M3(BTC)2 (M = Co, Ni), Zn3(BTC)2(DMF)3(H2O)⋅(DMF)(H2O), and Cd4(BTC)3(DMF)2(H2O)2⋅6(H2O) were reported, but, up to now, no such chiral compound with alkaline-earth metals has been described. 5-Aminoisophthalic acid (H2AIP) and calcium ions can form a double helix as in a compound with the formula of {[Ca(AIP)(OH2)4](H2O)}∞. In the most reported 3D calcium MOFs containing 1D chain motifs (see Table ), these chains do not have a helical shape; it is also the case of our compounds 1 and 2.

The H2dhtp anion was employed as a ligand in Ca MOFs with formulas [Ca(H2dhtp)2(H2O)2] (CPO-20) and [Ca(H2dhtp)2] (CPO-21). Compounds 4−6 represent another three new structures with this ligand with different topologies and framework connections. Compound 6 can be considered as a supramolecular isomer of CPO-20. However, the coordination numbers of the calcium ion, inorganic motifs, and the bridging models of the organic ligand are totally unlike each other (Table ). In conclusion, the variation of the reaction time, solvents used, pH values of the solution, chemicals ratio, etc. in the reactions results in five different calcium MOFs with the same metal ion and organic ligand. In the previously described MOFs based on calcium carboxylates containing DMF, the DMF molecules served as bridging ligands. In our compounds 1−5, the DMF molecule represents a terminal auxiliary ligand, which decreases the number of coordination sites at the central Ca atom available for the carboxylate ligands and thus helps to decrease the dimensionality of the resulting compounds.

elements.content: Solvent exchange with various organic solvents such as acetonitrile, dichloromethane, hexane, tetrahydrofuran, methanol, and ethanol in the compounds described above was studied as preliminary tests for further gas sorption examinations. It was found that the adsorptions of the solvents into these compounds are rather low. However, to our surprise, compounds 1, 4, and 5 treated with water containing methanol were found to produce new phases. As proved by further examinations, this methanol−water mixture has the strongest influence on the structural transformations while either no reaction or dissolution (or decomposition) was observed when other solvents were used. The structural transformations can be summarized in the following equations: [ Ca ( BDC ) ( DMF ) ( H 2 O ) ] ( 1 ) → MeOH / H 2 O [ Ca ( BDC ) ( H 2 O ) 3 ] ( 1 a ) ⇌ humidity Δ ( 1 b ) [ Ca ( H 2 dhtp ) 2 ( DMF ) 2 ] ( 4 ) → MeOH / H 2 O [ Ca ( H 2 dhtp ) 2 ( H 2 O ) 2 ] ( 4 a ) ⇌ humidity Δ [ Ca ( H 2 dhtp ) 2 ] ( 4 b ) [ Ca ( H 2 dhtp ) ( DMF ) 2 ] ( 5 ) → MeOH / H 2 O [ Ca ( H 2 dhtp ) 2 ( H 2 O ) 2 ] ( 4 a ) Generally, a removal of dimethylformamide and its replacement with water in the structures of the original compounds was observed. These structural changes can take place as dissolution/reorganization reactions involving a break and reformation of the Ca−O bond, in which the driving force might be the high hydration energy of water molecules to calcium ions (−1577 kJ/mol). This destruction/construction process leads to more stable metal coordination polymers. In the case of compounds 1a and 4a, water can be removed by heating. The removal of water is a reversible process and these dehydrated compounds (1b and 4b) take up water when kept in a humid environment.

elements.content: Thermogravimetry analyses () were performed to determine the thermal stability of the studied compounds. For 1 and 3, both first weight losses of about 30% below 400 °C correspond to the release of the coordinated water and DMF molecules. Compounds 2, 4, and 5 are stable up to about 250, 250, and 200 °C, respectively. For all complexes studied, further weight losses up to 800 °C correspond to the decomposition of the organic ligands. All final residuals are calcium oxide, as confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetry Analysis

Thermogravimetry analyses () were performed to determine the thermal stability of the studied compounds. For 1 and 3, both first weight losses of about 30% below 400 °C correspond to the release of the coordinated water and DMF molecules. Compounds 2, 4, and 5 are stable up to about 250, 250, and 200 °C, respectively. For all complexes studied, further weight losses up to 800 °C correspond to the decomposition of the organic ligands. All final residuals are calcium oxide, as confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: The diffuse reflectance UV−vis spectra of all compounds display two or three broad absorption bands in the range of 200−800 nm (). The first high energy band around 290 nm may be assigned to an intraligand transition from n to π* and π to π* by the carboxylate ligands of BDC, ABDC, BTC, and H2dhtp. To examine the luminescent properties, the solid state fluorescence spectra of 1−5 at room temperature are depicted in . The intense emissions concentrate at around 390 nm for 1 and 3 and 500 nm for 2, 4, and 5. These emissions are neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) and can probably be assigned to the intraligand fluorescent emission and the luminescent behavior of 1−5 might be rationalized by ligand-centered π or n to π* orbital transitions since similar emissions are also observed for free ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

The diffuse reflectance UV-vis spectra of all compounds display two or three broad absorption bands in the range of 200-800 nm (). The first high energy band around 290 nm may be assigned to an intraligand transition from n to π* and π to π* by the carboxylate ligands of BDC, ABDC, BTC, and H2dhtp. To examine the luminescent properties, the solid state fluorescence spectra of 1-5 at room temperature are depicted in . The intense emissions concentrate at around 390 nm for 1 and 3 and 500 nm for 2, 4, and 5. These emissions are neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) and can probably be assigned to the intraligand fluorescent emission and the luminescent behavior of 1-5 might be rationalized by ligand-centered π or n to π* orbital transitions since similar emissions are also observed for free ligands.

elements.content: In order to investigate porous properties of compounds 1−5, nitrogen adsorption and desorption were measured at 77 K. All compounds revealed almost no N2 uptake. Only the N2 adsorption isotherms of 1b and 4b () both show a moderate rise of the adsorbed amount of N2 at low relative pressure. The slope of the adsorption curve gets gradually higher at around P/P 0 = 0.7. These results indicate Type II isotherms. The isotherms steeply increase above 0.9 P/P 0 displaying the maximum adsorption amounts of 45.9 and 50.6 cm3 g−1 (for 1b and 4b, respectively), which indicate that most of the nitrogen is absorbed and some mesopores might form by intergranular space of both powder samples. Our results show that 1b and 4b possess BET surface area or Langmuir surface area of 27 and 18 or 39 and 32 m2 g−1, respectively, as calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms. The H2 adsorption isotherms of 1b and 4b () at 77 K and 1 atm correspond to unsaturated and linear isotherms with the values of 12.5 and 31.7 cm3 g−1, respectively. The H2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of these samples are slightly hysteretic. The degassed materials might contain unsaturated Ca(II) ions, polar residues, and electrons of the ligand, which may lead to weak interactions on the sample surface that induce a dipole in H2. The maximum CO2 adsorptions of 1b and 4b () at 298 K and 1 atm are 3.0 and 3.4 cm3 g−1, respectively. By fitting the adsorption data to the Dubinin−Radushkevich (DR) equation, the surface area was determined to be 36.4 and 45.1 m2 g−1. The moderate surface area and gas-storage capacity are likely related to poor diffusion of these gaseous molecules with their dynamic diameters and indicate that adsorption might take place at the external surface of the powder samples only.

elements.content: We have described here the assemblies and structures of six new calcium MOFs, which all have a 3D structure constructed from polycarboxylate ligands (BDC, ABDC, BTC, and H2dhtp) and calcium(II) ions. Rich structural variability of the prepared compound is accomplished by various coordination modes of the calcium cation as a connector going from the coordination number of six in compound 5 to seven in 3, 4, and 6 and to eight in 1, 2, and 3. The coordination variability is even richer in the polycarboxylate anions used as linkers with bridging modes μ n where n varies from 2 to 8, as summarized in Table . The CaO x polyhedra are either solitary units as in 5, or connected to form dimers as in 4 and 6, or 1D chains as in 1, 2, and 3. In all six compounds, these inorganic SBUs are connected through the polycarboxylate ligands to form 3D channel structures. In the case of 3, the channels are filled with lattice water molecules. N,N-Dimethylformamide serves as a terminal ligand in all compounds except 6 and thus decreases the number of coordination sites available for carboxylate groups and water. Water is coordinated to the central Ca atoms in 1, 3, and 6.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have described here the assemblies and structures of six new calcium MOFs, which all have a 3D structure constructed from polycarboxylate ligands (BDC, ABDC, BTC, and H2dhtp) and calcium(II) ions. Rich structural variability of the prepared compound is accomplished by various coordination modes of the calcium cation as a connector going from the coordination number of six in compound 5 to seven in 3, 4, and 6 and to eight in 1, 2, and 3. The coordination variability is even richer in the polycarboxylate anions used as linkers with bridging modes μ n  where n varies from 2 to 8, as summarized in Table . The CaO x  polyhedra are either solitary units as in 5, or connected to form dimers as in 4 and 6, or 1D chains as in 1, 2, and 3. In all six compounds, these inorganic SBUs are connected through the polycarboxylate ligands to form 3D channel structures. In the case of 3, the channels are filled with lattice water molecules. N,N-Dimethylformamide serves as a terminal ligand in all compounds except 6 and thus decreases the number of coordination sites available for carboxylate groups and water. Water is coordinated to the central Ca atoms in 1, 3, and 6.

elements.content: Chiral compound 3 represents the most interesting structure. Its helical inorganic chains are formed by edge-shared CaO7 and CaO8 polyhedra which are in addition connected through 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate ligands. To the best of our knowledge, this compound is the first example of chiral calcium carboxylate prepared from achiral precursors.

Its helical inorganic chains are formed by edge-shared CaO7 and CaO8 polyhedra which are in addition connected through 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate ligands. To the best of our knowledge, this compound is the first example of chiral calcium carboxylate prepared from achiral precursors.

A reaction mixture of bis(2-hydroxyethyl)1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (C12H14O6, H2BHET, 0.0508 g, 0.2 mmol), Ca(NO3)2 ·4H2O (0.0945 g, 0.4 mmol), H2O (1.0 mL), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 5.0 mL) was stirred for 20 min at room temperature forming a homogeneous solution with a pH value of 6.40. The solution was heated at 150 °C for 2 days. Colorless crystals of 1 were filtered off, washed with DMF, dried at 50 °C in an oven, and collected with the yield of 0.027 g (47.99%, based on the H2BHET reagent). Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 43.90/44.74; N, 4.65/4.74; H, 4.41/4.44% for 1. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3505(br), 3467(br), 3304(br), 1667(w), 1618(w), 1558(s), 1509(m), 1438(s), 1394(s), 1312(w), 1108(w), 1021(w), 869(w), 846(w), 700(w), 674(w), 513(w).

Synthesis of [Ca(ABDC)(DMF)] (<bold>2</bold>)

A reaction mixture of 2-aminoterephthalic acid (C8H7NO4, H2ABDC, 0.0362 g, 0.2 mmol), Ca(NO3)2 ·4H2O (0.0945 g, 0.4 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 7.0 mL), ethanol (2.0 mL), and H2O (1.0 mL) was stirred for 20 min at room temperature forming a homogeneous solution with the pH value of 4.39. The solution was heated at 90 °C for 2 days. Colorless crystals of 2 were filtered off, washed with DMF, dried at 50 °C in an oven, and collected with the yield of 0.0416 g (71.23%, based on the H2ABDC reagent). Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 45.46/45.20; N, 9.46/9.58; H, 3.76/4.14% for 2. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3465(m), 3340(m), 2933(w), 1648(s), 1561(s), 1491(s), 1409(m), 1385(s), 1250(m), 1105(m), 842(w), 775(w), 670(w), 511(w).

Synthesis of [Ca<sub>3</sub>(BTC)<sub>2</sub>(DMF)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (C9H6O6, H3BTC, 0.021 g, 0.1 mmol), Ca(NO3)2 ·4H2O (0.0708 g, 0.3 mmol), H2O (1.0 mL), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 5.0 mL) was stirred for 20 min at room temperature forming a homogeneous solution with a pH value of 3.92. Then a formic acid solution (HCO2H, 0.4 M, 0.1 mL) was added causing a decrease of pH to 3.50. The resulting solution was heated at 90 °C for 2 days. The colorless crystals of 3 were filtered off, washed with DMF, dried at 50 °C in an oven, and collected with a yield of 0.0073 g (9.5%, based on the H3BTC reagent). Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 37.69/37.40; N, 3.96/3.63; H, 4.26/3.92% for 2. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3495(br), 3405(br), 1662(s), 1613(s), 1547(s), 1442(s), 1378(s), 1107(m), 773(m), 731(m), 714(m), 665(w).

Synthesis of [Ca(H<sub>2</sub>dhtp)(DMF)] (<bold>4</bold>) and [Ca(H<sub>2</sub>dhtp)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>6</bold>)

A mixture of 2,5-dihydroxy-terephthalic acid (C8H6O6, H4dhtp, 0.0397 g, 0.2 mmol), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0945 g, 0.4 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 7.0 mL), EtOH (2.0 mL), and H2O (1.0 mL) was stirred for 20 min at room temperature forming a homogeneous solution with the pH value of 3.05. The solution was heated at 120 °C for 2 days. The pale-yellow crystals of 4 were filtered off, washed with DMF, dried at 50 °C in an oven, and collected with a yield of 0.0645 g (52.31%, based on the H4dhtp reagent). The product contained only a few colorless crystals of 6 which were selected manually from the mixture with 4 and characterized by single crystal analysis. Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 42.12/42.86; N, 4.58/4.54; H, 3.77/3.27% for 4. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3432(br), 3071(w), 2967(w), 2935(w), 2722(w), 1670(m), 1632(m), 1501(s), 1446(s), 1349(m), 1244(m), 1108(m), 920(m), 862(m), 801(m), 786(m) for 4.

Microwave-Assisted Synthesis of [Ca(H<sub>2</sub>dhtp)(DMF)] (<bold>4</bold>)

The single phase of 4 can be also obtained under microwave-assisted conditions from the same reaction mixture as described above in a solvothermal reaction by heating at 120 °C for 20 min. The pale-yellow crystals of the product were collected with the yield of 0.0460 g (74.36%, based on H4dhtp reagent).

Synthesis of [Ca(H<sub>2</sub>dhtp)(DMF)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>)

A reaction mixture of 2,5-dihydroxy-terephthalic acid (C8H6O6, H4dhtp, 0.0397 g, 0.2 mmol), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0945 g, 0.4 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 7.0 mL), ethanol (2.0 mL), and H2O (1.0 mL) was stirred for 20 min at room temperature forming a homogeneous solution with the pH value of 3.12. The solution was heated at 90 °C for 2 days. The pale-yellow crystals of 5 were collected with the yield of 0.0452 g (59.14%, based on the H4dhtp reagent). Elemental analysis found/calcd.: C, 43.70/43.97; N, 7.45/7.33; H, 5.47/4.74% for 5. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3448(w), 3389(w), 2933(w), 1664(s), 1608(s), 1490(s), 1448(s), 1385(m), 1242(m), 1109(m), 863(m), 820(m), 786(m), 675(w), 609(w), 537(w) for 5.

cln_elements.content:
Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 1 possesses an extended 3D framework. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ca atom, one BDC ligand, one DMF, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The Ca(II) ion is eight-coordinated and binds six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups belonging to four BDC ligands, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom from DMF with the typical Ca−O bond values from 2.366(5) to 2.557(3) Å. The BDC anion bonds to four different Ca(II) ions and adopts a symmetric tetradentate (κ2)-(κ1-κ2-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). Each carboxylate group chelates one calcium atom. As shown in Figure b, CaO8 distorted tetragonal antiprisms share edges and create inorganic motifs in the form of zigzag 1D chains running along the a axis. These chains are linked together by μ4 links of the BDC ligands in two directions to generate the 3D MOF of 1 (Figure c) with rhomboidal channels running along the a-axis, which have a cross section of about 15.5 × 5.6 Å2. The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. The solvent accessible volume (SAV) calculated without including DMF and water molecules by PLATON analysis is 646.2 Å3, which is 47.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 1 can be described as a sra net (), as defined by the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource, or a uninodal 4-connected net with Schläfli symbol of {42.63.8}, determined using TOPOS. This topology, despite its simplicity, is rather unusual and, in the group of metal carboxylates, it was found in cobalt(II) coordination complex with 1,3-benzenecarboxylate and in cadmium(II) compound with cysteic acid.

Structural Description of [Ca(H<sub>2</sub>dhtp)(DMF)] (<bold>4</bold>)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 4 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, two types of half-H2dhtp ligand, and one DMF molecule (Figure a). The H2dhtp ligand displays two different types of coordination models, one binds to four calcium atoms with two carboxylate groups adopting a tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a); the other binds to six calcium atoms with two carboxylate group and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms adopting a hexadentate (κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a). The Ca(1) center is seven-coordinated and binds five oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from five H2dhtp ligands, one oxygen atom of the hydroxyl groups of H2dhtp, and one oxygen atom of DMF. Two Ca(1) polyhedra share edges and thus form of Ca2O12 dimers. These dimers are connected to each other through two carboxylic groups in a Ca(1)−O−C−O−Ca(1) bonding system of two tetradentate ligands. In addition, two hexadentate ligands bridge two dimers through their carboxyl and OH group oxygen atoms. In this way, a chain of SBUs is formed which runs along the a axis (Figure b). The chains are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to generate a 3D framework (Figure c) with channels running along the a axis direction and having a cross section of about 6.0 × 5.7 Å2 (considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 535.8 Å3, which is 41.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis () revealed that compound 4 exhibits a 4,5,6-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {42.84}{46.66.83}{48.62}2.

Structural Description of [Ca(H<sub>2</sub>dhtp)(DMF)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 5 possesses an extended 3D structure with the space group C2/c, in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, one H2dhtp ligand, and two DMF ligands (Figure a). The calcium ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from four H2dhtp ligands and two oxygen atoms from the DMF ligands forming a CaO6 octahedron. The H2dhtp ligand binds to four calcium atoms in a tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). The discrete octahedra of CaO6 (Figure b) are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure c) of 5 with channels running along the c-axis and having a square-grid size of about 7.4 × 7.4 Å2 (O(3)···O(3) × O(3)···O(3), considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. The SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 1009.2 Å3, which is 56.9% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 5 exhibits a 4-connected pts net () with a Schläfli symbol of {42.84}.

Structural Description of [Ca(H<sub>2</sub>dhtp)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>6</bold>)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that compound 6 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, four H2dhtp ligands, and two H2O ligands (Figure a). The Ca center is seven-coordinated and connects to four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from four H2dhtp ligands, one oxygen atom of the hydroxyl groups from one H2dhtp ligand, and two oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules. The H2dhtp ligand displays two coordination behaviors: one of the H2dhtp ligands binds to six calcium atoms with a symmetric hexadendate (κ1-μ2)-(κ2)-(κ1-μ2)-(κ2)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a); the other type of H2dhtp ligand binds to two calcium atoms with two carboxylate groups adopting a bis-monodentate (κ1)-(κ1)-μ2 coordination mode (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, the dimers of Ca2O12 are formed by edge sharing two CaO7 polyhedra and are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to generate a 3D framework. In the structure, small channels which run along the a axis and contain coordinated water molecules are present. The SAV calculated without including water molecules by PLATON analysis is only 24.5 Å3, which is 5.0% of the unit cell volume. According to topological analysis compound 6 contains a 4,6-connected fsh net () with a Schläfli symbol of {43.63}2{46.66.83}.

Thermogravimetry Analysis

Thermogravimetry analyses () were performed to determine the thermal stability of the studied compounds. For 1 and 3, both first weight losses of about 30% below 400 °C correspond to the release of the coordinated water and DMF molecules. Compounds 2, 4, and 5 are stable up to about 250, 250, and 200 °C, respectively. For all complexes studied, further weight losses up to 800 °C correspond to the decomposition of the organic ligands. All final residuals are calcium oxide, as confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction.

Sorption Properties

In order to investigate porous properties of compounds 1−5, nitrogen adsorption and desorption were measured at 77 K. All compounds revealed almost no N2 uptake. Only the N2 adsorption isotherms of 1b and 4b () both show a moderate rise of the adsorbed amount of N2 at low relative pressure. The slope of the adsorption curve gets gradually higher at around P/P 0 = 0.7. These results indicate Type II isotherms. The isotherms steeply increase above 0.9 P/P 0 displaying the maximum adsorption amounts of 45.9 and 50.6 cm3 g−1 (for 1b and 4b, respectively), which indicate that most of the nitrogen is absorbed and some mesopores might form by intergranular space of both powder samples. Our results show that 1b and 4b possess BET surface area or Langmuir surface area of 27 and 18 or 39 and 32 m2 g−1, respectively, as calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms. The H2 adsorption isotherms of 1b and 4b () at 77 K and 1 atm correspond to unsaturated and linear isotherms with the values of 12.5 and 31.7 cm3 g−1, respectively. The H2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of these samples are slightly hysteretic. The degassed materials might contain unsaturated Ca(II) ions, polar residues, and electrons of the ligand, which may lead to weak interactions on the sample surface that induce a dipole in H2. The maximum CO2 adsorptions of 1b and 4b () at 298 K and 1 atm are 3.0 and 3.4 cm3 g−1, respectively. By fitting the adsorption data to the Dubinin−Radushkevich (DR) equation, the surface area was determined to be 36.4 and 45.1 m2 g−1. The moderate surface area and gas-storage capacity are likely related to poor diffusion of these gaseous molecules with their dynamic diameters and indicate that adsorption might take place at the external surface of the powder samples only.

The asymmetric unit consists of one Ca atom, one BDC ligand, one DMF, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The Ca(II) ion is eight-coordinated and binds six oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups belonging to four BDC ligands, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, and one oxygen atom from DMF with the typical Ca-O bond values from 2.366(5) to 2.557(3) Å. The BDC anion bonds to four different Ca(II) ions and adopts a symmetric tetradentate (κ2)-(κ1-κ2-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). Each carboxylate group chelates one calcium atom. As shown in Figure b, CaO8 distorted tetragonal antiprisms share edges and create inorganic motifs in the form of zigzag 1D chains running along the a axis. These chains are linked together by μ4 links of the BDC ligands in two directions to generate the 3D MOF of 1 (Figure c) with rhomboidal channels running along the a-axis, which have a cross section of about 15.5 × 5.6 Å2. The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. The solvent accessible volume (SAV) calculated without including DMF and water molecules by PLATON analysis is 646.2 Å3, which is 47.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 1 can be described as a sra net (), as defined by the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource, or a uninodal 4-connected net with Schläfli symbol of {42.63.8}, determined using TOPOS. This topology, despite its simplicity, is rather unusual and, in the group of metal carboxylates, it was found in cobalt(II) coordination complex with 1,3-benzenecarboxylate and in cadmium(II) compound with cysteic acid. 

Structural Description of [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)] (4)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 4 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, two types of half-H2dhtp ligand, and one DMF molecule (Figure a). The H2dhtp ligand displays two different types of coordination models, one binds to four calcium atoms with two carboxylate groups adopting a tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a); the other binds to six calcium atoms with two carboxylate group and two hydroxyl oxygen atoms adopting a hexadentate (κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a). The Ca(1) center is seven-coordinated and binds five oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from five H2dhtp ligands, one oxygen atom of the hydroxyl groups of H2dhtp, and one oxygen atom of DMF. Two Ca(1) polyhedra share edges and thus form of Ca2O12 dimers. These dimers are connected to each other through two carboxylic groups in a Ca(1)-O-C-O-Ca(1) bonding system of two tetradentate ligands. In addition, two hexadentate ligands bridge two dimers through their carboxyl and OH group oxygen atoms. In this way, a chain of SBUs is formed which runs along the a axis (Figure b). The chains are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to generate a 3D framework (Figure c) with channels running along the a axis direction and having a cross section of about 6.0 × 5.7 Å2 (considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 535.8 Å3, which is 41.2% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis () revealed that compound 4 exhibits a 4,5,6-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {42.84}{46.66.83}{48.62}2.

Structural Description of [Ca(H2dhtp)(DMF)2] (5)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction shows that the structure of compound 5 possesses an extended 3D structure with the space group C2/c, in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, one H2dhtp ligand, and two DMF ligands (Figure a). The calcium ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from four H2dhtp ligands and two oxygen atoms from the DMF ligands forming a CaO6 octahedron. The H2dhtp ligand binds to four calcium atoms in a tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure a). The discrete octahedra of CaO6 (Figure b) are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure c) of 5 with channels running along the c-axis and having a square-grid size of about 7.4 × 7.4 Å2 (O(3)⋅⋅⋅O(3) × O(3)⋅⋅⋅O(3), considering the van der Waals radii of oxygen atoms). The coordinated DMF molecules point toward the channels. The SAV calculated without including DMF molecules by PLATON analysis is 1009.2 Å3, which is 56.9% of the unit cell volume. Topological analysis revealed that compound 5 exhibits a 4-connected pts net () with a Schläfli symbol of {42.84}.

Structural Description of [Ca(H2dhtp)2(H2O)2] (6)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that compound 6 possesses an extended 3D framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Ca center, four H2dhtp ligands, and two H2O ligands (Figure a). The Ca center is seven-coordinated and connects to four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate groups from four H2dhtp ligands, one oxygen atom of the hydroxyl groups from one H2dhtp ligand, and two oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules. The H2dhtp ligand displays two coordination behaviors: one of the H2dhtp ligands binds to six calcium atoms with a symmetric hexadendate (κ1-μ2)-(κ2)-(κ1-μ2)-(κ2)-μ6 coordination mode (Figure a); the other type of H2dhtp ligand binds to two calcium atoms with two carboxylate groups adopting a bis-monodentate (κ1)-(κ1)-μ2 coordination mode (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, the dimers of Ca2O12 are formed by edge sharing two CaO7 polyhedra and are bridged by the H2dhtp ligands to generate a 3D framework. In the structure, small channels which run along the a axis and contain coordinated water molecules are present. The SAV calculated without including water molecules by PLATON analysis is only 24.5 Å3, which is 5.0% of the unit cell volume. According to topological analysis compound 6 contains a 4,6-connected fsh net () with a Schläfli symbol of {43.63}2{46.66.83}.

Thermogravimetry Analysis

Thermogravimetry analyses () were performed to determine the thermal stability of the studied compounds. For 1 and 3, both first weight losses of about 30% below 400 °C correspond to the release of the coordinated water and DMF molecules. Compounds 2, 4, and 5 are stable up to about 250, 250, and 200 °C, respectively. For all complexes studied, further weight losses up to 800 °C correspond to the decomposition of the organic ligands. All final residuals are calcium oxide, as confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction.

Sorption Properties

In order to investigate porous properties of compounds 1-5, nitrogen adsorption and desorption were measured at 77 K. All compounds revealed almost no N2 uptake. Only the N2 adsorption isotherms of 1b and 4b () both show a moderate rise of the adsorbed amount of N2 at low relative pressure. The slope of the adsorption curve gets gradually higher at around P/P 0 = 0.7. These results indicate Type II isotherms. The isotherms steeply increase above 0.9 P/P 0 displaying the maximum adsorption amounts of 45.9 and 50.6 cm3 g-1 (for 1b and 4b, respectively), which indicate that most of the nitrogen is absorbed and some mesopores might form by intergranular space of both powder samples. Our results show that 1b and 4b possess BET surface area or Langmuir surface area of 27 and 18 or 39 and 32 m2 g-1, respectively, as calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms. The H2 adsorption isotherms of 1b and 4b () at 77 K and 1 atm correspond to unsaturated and linear isotherms with the values of 12.5 and 31.7 cm3 g-1, respectively. The H2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of these samples are slightly hysteretic. The degassed materials might contain unsaturated Ca(II) ions, polar residues, and electrons of the ligand, which may lead to weak interactions on the sample surface that induce a dipole in H2. The maximum CO2 adsorptions of 1b and 4b () at 298 K and 1 atm are 3.0 and 3.4 cm3 g-1, respectively. By fitting the adsorption data to the Dubinin-Radushkevich (DR) equation, the surface area was determined to be 36.4 and 45.1 m2 g-1. The moderate surface area and gas-storage capacity are likely related to poor diffusion of these gaseous molecules with their dynamic diameters and indicate that adsorption might take place at the external surface of the powder samples only.
